awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding and exploiting the structure-function link between fatty acid biosynthesis and degradation enzymes for functionalized small molecule synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Commercially important products are often built up from small molecules. Bacteria and other microbes are proficient at producing such molecules. Many are synthesized from fats and fatty acids. Understanding how the cells make and modify fats will help determine how to make renewable fuels and chemicals in large amounts using microbes. The project will also help educate our society in the challenges and opportunities on the road to a sustainable future. This includes advising and training of undergraduate and high school students from school districts serving predominantly minority populations. Together, these efforts will provide academic and industrial training in areas of strategic national importance.

Insight into the evolutionary divergence of fatty acid biosynthesis (FAB) and beta-oxidation (BOX) pathways will be sought by characterizing enzyme/substrate interactions and the unique characteristics of enzymes from various organisms. Using non-decarboxylative condensation and β-reduction reactions, molecules with novel functionalities will be generated.  Type II FAB and BOX enzymes will be used interchangeably to capitalize on the advantageous characteristics of each set of enzymes. An integrated approach in which computational protein modeling and design will guide experimentation through molecular modeling of the FAB and BOX enzymes with a wide array of biosynthetically accessible compounds will be undertaken. The specific objectives of the project are: 1) computational protein modeling and design of type II FAB and BOX enzymes; 2) in vitro characterization of type II FAB and BOX enzymes; and 3) in vivo construction and characterization of combinations of type II FAB and BOX enzymes. Medium chain (C5-C8) dicarboxylic and methyl-branched carboxylic acids, specifically dicarboxylates adipic (C6) and suberic (C8) acids and methyl-branched unsaturated tiglic acid (C5) will be produced.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
USF has significantly advanced the field of microbial metabolic engineering by developing novel tools and pathways for the sustainable production of high-value chemicals and fuels. The outcomes of this project are summarized as follows:

  1. Comprehensive Review of Reverse β-Oxidation (rBOX) Pathways
    USF published a comprehensive review that summarized recent advancements in rBOX pathway engineering and its potential applications for producing diverse chemicals and materials. This work highlighted the modularity of rBOX pathways, their minimal enzyme requirements, and their capability for iterative elongation of carbon molecules without ATP dependency. The review also discussed the broader applicability of rBOX pathways for integrating various feedstocks, such as glycerol, carbon dioxide, and methane, into sustainable chemical production pipelines.
  2. Selective Production of 1-Decanol
    USF successfully engineered Escherichia coli to selectively produce 1-decanol, an important industrial compound. Key innovations included optimizing rBOX pathway expression, enhancing acyl-CoA reductase termination enzyme specificity, and implementing bi-phasic fermentation strategies. These efforts resulted in 1-decanol titers, yields, and purities that are at least 10-fold higher than previously reported. This achievement underscores the scalability and industrial relevance of the rBOX pathway for long-chain alcohol production.
  3. Orthogonal Gene Expression Control for Metabolic Flux Optimization
    To overcome metabolic flux bottlenecks in iterative pathways like rBOX, USF developed a plasmid-based inducible system (TriO) for orthogonal control of gene expression. This system enabled precise control over pathway flux, significantly improving product specificity and yield. Experimental validation demonstrated titers close to 90% of the theoretical maximum yield for key products, including 6.3 g/L of butyrate, 2.2 g/L of butanol, and 4.0 g/L of hexanoate. These results illustrate the utility of orthogonal gene expression control for optimizing complex pathways in synthetic biology.
  4. Broader Applications and Impacts
    USF’s methodologies and tools provide a versatile platform for engineering iterative pathways and optimizing metabolic flux. By reducing the cost, time, and infrastructure required for pathway design and testing, these innovations democratize access to synthetic biology tools for researchers worldwide. Additionally, the insights gained from USF’s research contribute to the development of sustainable biochemical production from renewable feedstocks, advancing the goals of a circular bioeconomy.

These outcomes collectively represent significant progress by USF in microbial metabolic engineering, offering new strategies for high-efficiency bioproduction of valuable chemicals. The findings have potential applications in industrial biotechnology, resource sustainability, and beyond.

 


Last Modified: 02/03/2025
Modified by: Norma A Alcantar
